outline.text: Roll no : IIT2023153
Company : Salesforce
Salesforce Internship Interview Experience (SDE Role)
Hey everyone! I'm Atharva Narkhede, currently pursuing my B.Tech
in Information Technology at IIIT Allahabad. Here's a detailed
write-up of my off-campus interview experience for the Software
Developer Summer Internship at Salesforce.
The OA consisted of 3 coding questions and questions on core CS
fundamentals like DSA, OOPS, OS, and DBMS. The coding questions
were: - Prefix Sum (Medium) - Trees (Hard) - Graph (Hard) It was a
solid test of problem-solving under pressure and theoretical clarity.
I received the interview call after clearing the OA. The technical
round was intense and broken into three parts: 1. DSA Round: - BST
(medium) and Linked List (medium) problems were asked. - I
explained my approach clearly and discussed edge cases, time/
space complexities.
The code was to be made run on hackerank interface , with the
expectations that all the test cases should pass. 2. OOPS Round: - I
was asked to explain abstraction, followed by a comparison
between abstract classes and interfaces. - I also implemented a
scenario using both to demonstrate understanding.
oriented. Questions like: - "Which data structure would you use to
revisit website pages and jump to forward ones?" → I answered
using Stack + LinkedList. - "What data structure would you use for
a stream of data like bits on physical media?" - I was struggling
with different approaches here, but stayed calm and walked
through my thoughts. The interviewer gave a hint, and I finally
landed on the correct structure: a Map. This was a moment of relief
and confidence boost.
##Tip: Even if you're unsure, communicate your thinking. The
interviewer values structured thought more than immediate
accuracy.
This was a blend of technical questions on projects and HR-based
questions
The interviewer reviewed my resume for over 10 mins and started
with the projects section : 1. Projects: - I explained my RAG-based
legal chatbot project. - I was asked: "Why RAG and not model fine-
tuning?" and had to justify the tech choices and trade-offs.
The interviewer asked what made u bulid this project? The answer
was straightforward as I had to solve a real world social problem
and bridge a gap between technical aspect and solving social cause.
skills I’m improving. - One tough moment: I was asked, "What’s
your biggest weakness?" - I answered using the STAR method
(Situation, Task, Action, Result), but the interviewer seemed a bit
skeptical. - She even counter-questioned it, and for a moment I
thought I blew my chances. - But surprisingly, she appreciated the
STAR structure and my composed handling of the situation.
Final Tips
- Start with Striver’s DSA Sheet for structured prep. - Practice 1200–
extremely comfortable with your projects and tech stack. - Maintain
clarity and confidence in your answers. - Don’t pretend to know
everything—stay humble and receptive.
Conclusion
I’m thrilled to share that I made it to the Salesforce Summer
Internship! The journey taught me not just technical prep, but the
importance of communication, resilience, and staying true to the
process. If you're prepping for such roles — stay consistent,
communicate well, and trust your journey!
